Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: They notice a few swimmers occasionally drifting toward deeper water but no immediate danger arises.
Story: This morning, I woke up early to help my husband prepare for his relatives’ visit. The house was a whirlwind of laundry, dusting, and last-minute grocery runs. He counted on me to make everything perfect, and I could see the stress in his eyes as he asked if I’d be home in time to help set the table. But my shift at the pool started at noon, and as a lifeguard, I couldn’t just leave early or let my attention wander. Even now, as I scan the water, I catch glimpses of swimmers edging toward the deep end. They’re not in trouble, but I know how quickly things can change. My phone buzzes with a message from my husband: “Can you pick up dessert on your way home?” I feel the weight of both worlds pressing on me—my duty to keep these swimmers safe, and my promise to be the supportive wife my husband needs today. My heart pounds as I try to figure out how I can possibly be in two places at once, knowing that no matter what I choose, I’ll be letting someone down.
